stream_context.summary: Kaze’s weekly dev stream focused on optimisation work and building a new ice-themed “Raven” enemy for Return to Yoshi’s Island 64.  He demonstrated recent engine refactors, explained micro-optimisations needed to keep 60 FPS on real N64 hardware, and debated core movement mechanics after outside feedback.

development_findings.summary: Refactored core RTYI code; crashes fixed and ROM runs again on physical N64 hardware.
development_findings.quote: I spent some time this week refactoring some of the RTUI code base… fixed a lot of crashes. The game is a lot more stable now.

development_findings.summary: First overworld temporarily replaced with a new debug overworld to isolate issues during refactor.
New HUD delegate/render system saves ~2 microseconds each frame.
development_findings.quote: The new system allows us to just render HUD elements anytime we want… we gain like probably two microseconds globally from that.

development_findings.summary: Planned optimisation: move frame buffers into separate memory segments for an estimated 2-3 % speed gain (≈1 FPS).
development_findings.quote: I’m gonna try putting the frame buffers into separate memory segments… probably like another two to three percent which, you know, that’s like a full FPS.

development_findings.summary: Finished ‘Freezy’ enemy and moved on to ‘Raven’ enemy implementation.
development_findings.quote: I think he’s done. I think we can move on to the next thing.

development_findings.summary: Initial Raven design (walk on geometry) pivoted to ‘ice minion’ that pops out of ground, walks a fixed path, then despawns—simpler to program and better thematically.
development_findings.quote: Pop out of ground, walk forwards, around the corner and then just disappear back in? Yeah, that would be so much easier to program.

development_findings.summary: Raven technical details: pop-up animation tied to velocity; hitbox 72 radius; 2 damage; bounce-top interaction; shadow bug solved by adjusting export maths.
Boss version ‘Raph the Raven’ planned for same course with moon/cosmic mechanics distinct from small enemies.
development_findings.quote: Raph the Raven is gonna be a boss in this course… there’s definitely gonna be some moon and cosmic elements to it.

development_findings.summary: Considering nerfing the dive-jump (angle change) after feedback from Dan Salvato to stay faithful to Mario 64 commitment philosophy.
development_findings.quote: This lets you change your angle in midair and nothing else in Mario 64 does… thinking of limiting the use of the dive a little bit more.

development_findings.summary: Project status: 13 regular courses modelled; Bowser levels, two side levels, major overworld, bug-testing still pending; no ETA but “two to three years” estimate.

context_findings.summary: Kaze views development as an enormous personal challenge: “like scaling 50 Everests.”
context_findings.quote: Making this game is honestly like scaling 50 Everests.

context_findings.summary: Works on the hack roughly once a week and is comfortable with a ‘done when it’s done’ timeline.
context_findings.quote: I just work on it like once a week at most… It’s done when it’s done.

context_findings.summary: Health/fitness routine overlaps stream; began out of breath from heavy squats and drank a high-protein ‘cum shake’ prepared by Zeina.
Design philosophy: prefers new ideas over ‘same-y’ platform hacks; optimisation for real hardware is a core value.
context_findings.quote: To me, games is about experiencing new ideas and concepts… The N64 is so much stronger than people give it credit for.

context_findings.summary: Engages openly with community feedback (e.g., Dan Salvato’s critique, chat suggestions) and may release Course 1 demos for public physics feedback.

biobak.summary: Suggested turning Ravens into ice minions that pop out of surfaces, influencing final design pivot.
biobak.quote: Just like ice minions popping out… That could work. It’s cooler and easier to program.

biobak.summary: Acts as French-speaking moderator and arrives during ‘cum shake’ segment; offers visual feedback on enemy colours/materials.

zeina.summary: Provided the Raven model/animations; Kaze requested tweaks (e.g., animation speed) and material variations.
Prepared the on-stream protein ‘cum shake’ and bantered with Kaze, illustrating personal/professional overlap.

key_stories.title: The Raven Pivot
key_stories.summary: Kaze initially codes a complex wall-walking Raven but, after Biobak’s suggestion, pivots to an ice minion that simply pops out, walks, and despawns. The change both simplifies programming and fits the surreal ice-palace theme.
key_stories.challenge: Original behaviour required tricky ray-cast navigation on uneven geometry.
key_stories.process: Biobak proposes pop-out behaviour; Kaze instantly prototypes new spawn logic, adjusts materials, and fixes export/math bugs.
key_stories.outcome: Working prototype completed during stream; larger boss version planned.
key_stories.key_quote: Pop out of ground, walk forwards, around the corner and then just disappear back in? Yeah, that would be so much easier to program.

key_stories.title: Rethinking the Dive Jump
key_stories.summary: External feedback makes Kaze question a core movement mechanic that lets players change direction mid-air. He outlines a potential nerf and even considers public test builds to choose final physics.
key_stories.challenge: Dive jump may conflict with Mario 64’s commitment-based design and be too hard for novices.
key_stories.process: Discusses Dan Salvato’s critique, brainstorms reduced angle influence proportional to stick tilt, and contemplates multiple demo builds for community polling.
key_stories.outcome: No decision yet; open design question.
key_stories.key_quote: I’m thinking of limiting the use of the dive a little bit more… find physics that people like the most.

key_stories.title: Microseconds Matter
key_stories.summary: Kaze shows his obsession with squeezing performance from 1996 hardware, unveiling a new HUD delegate system and plotting a frame-buffer memory trick.
key_stories.challenge: Maintain near-60 FPS on real N64 despite growing visual complexity.
key_stories.process: Refactors HUD to dynamic delegates (+2 µs), explains planned memory-segment split for another 1 FPS, and demonstrates on-stream profiling.
key_stories.outcome: Stable build now runs again on hardware; further optimisation scheduled.
key_stories.key_quote: We save a few precious microseconds in every level… probably like another two to three percent which is a full FPS.
